Monday, May 21, 2007























Senators announce bipartisan immigration deal
After three months of negotiations, a bipartisan group of senators said Thursday they have crafted an immigration bill that would give the estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants a path to citizenship. 
FULL STORY


























The Situation Room, weekdays 4 p.m. & 7 p.m. ET
Watch "The Situation Room," anchored by Wolf Blitzer, for complete, up-to-the minute coverage of the day's events. Tune in to "The Situation Room" weekdays from 4 to 6 p.m. and from 7 to 8 p.m. ET.

For a daily sneak preview of the show and an early read on the day's political news sign up for "The Situation Room" daily email newsletter at http://www.CNN.com/situationroom.






















GOP presidential debate turns feisty
The leading Republican presidential contenders defended their conservative credentials Tuesday night, parrying attacks on their positions on abortion, gun control and tax cuts.
FULL STORY






Wolfowitz to resign as World Bank chief
President Bush sounded as if he was resigned to the fact that World Bank President Paul Wolfowitz's tenure was coming to an end. "I regret that it's come to this," Bush said.
FULL STORY






Richardson touts roots, resume
New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson officially entered the 2008 presidential contest highlighting his resume and Latino heritage. An Iowa poll showed Richardson running fourth.
FULL STORY






Specter expects Gonzales to resign
The top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee said Thursday that he expects the investigation into the firings of federal prosecutors will lead to Attorney General Alberto Gonzales' resignation.
FULL STORY
